Measurement instruments that use these criteria have acceptable to good [[internal consistency]] and low to moderate [[test-retest]] [[Reliability (statistics)|reliability]] (''[[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient|r]]'' in the range of 0.35 to 0.67).<ref name="CSVperspective">{{cite book|last=Harter|first=Andrew C.|title=[[Character Strengths and Virtues (book)|Character Strengths and Virtues: A Handbook and Classification]]|editor=Peterson, Christopher and [[Martin Seligman|Seligman, Martin E. Measurement instruments that use these criteria have acceptable to good [[internal consistency]] and low to moderate [[test-retest]] [[Reliability (statistics)|reliability]] (''[[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient|r]]'' in the range of 0.35 to 0.67).<ref name="CSVperspective">{{cite book|last=Harter|first=Andrew C.|title=[[Character Strengths and Virtues (book)|Character Strengths and Virtues: A Handbook and Classification]]|editor=Peterson, Christopher and [[Martin Seligman|Seligman, Martin E. P.]]|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|chapter=8|year=2004|location=Oxford|pages=181–196|isbn=0-19-516701-5}}</ref>

[[John Vervaeke]] has argued for a cognitive science of wisdom and argues that basic [[relevance realization]] processes that underlie cognition, when fed back onto themselves and made self-referential lead to the enhanced insight abilities we associated with wisdom. <ref>{{cite book|last=Ferrari|first=Michel|title=The Scientific Study of Personal Wisdom.|year=2012|publisher=Springer Verlag|isbn=978-9048192304}}</ref>
+
[[John Vervaeke]] has argued for a cognitive science of wisdom and argues that basic [[relevance realization]] processes that underlie cognition, when fed back onto themselves and made self-referential lead to the enhanced insight abilities we associated with wisdom. <ref>{{cite book|last=Ferrari|first=Michel|title=The Scientific Study of Personal Wisdom.|year=2012|publisher=Springer Verlag|isbn=978-9048192304}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|last=Vervaeke|first=John|title=The Cognitive Science of Wisdom|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ti4Kj8TcEgk|publisher=Mind Matters Conference|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref>
